fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (01:39): for, example
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9: does it render wrong or something?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): seems ok to me...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:40): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Perhaps the laws of physics changed on the day of your experiment?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:40): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Perhaps
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:40): fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9: oh i guess the <!-- in the <style> element isn't closed

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:41): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: If you did the experiment right and analysed it properly, nobody can complain just because your conclusions don't match the expected answer :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:41): fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9: hm, that would break in html5, huh
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:41): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Obviously the spec isn't compatible with existing content.
fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (01:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yes, the whole thing ends up in that comment :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): clearly
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:42): fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9: i'll file it, thanks
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:42): And fix HTML 5 so it's compatible with the web?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:42): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I am well aware :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:46): sadly the reason html5 isn't compatible with this is that what the browsers do is a security bug
fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (01:46): reparsing sucks :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:46): How so?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:46): is probably missing something obvious
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:49): fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9: filed, thanks
fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (01:50): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: thankyou

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:51): I reported that back in the spring, right?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:53): happened to see it just now since i had to look at the bug database :-)
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:53): I probably wasn't on IRC when it was fixed, assuming it was in the [June, October] range
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:54): I need to actually remember everything related to uncertainties instead of looking it up every time.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:55): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: you reported it last april, it was fixed for good in june
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (01:55): yeah, that was around the start of my A.T. thru-hike, didn't get back on IRC until October 26 or 27
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:01): cool
a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:05): anyone available that would be able to help answer a parsing question with html5lib?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:06): a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82: Probably, depending on what the question is

a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I've got source code in a <code> tag that has <>= etc. in it that are confusing the parser. The tree that comes out is pretty mangled. If I change the <code> tags to <textarea> the contentFlag gets set to CDATA and it works, but it doesn't seem to do that for pre or code

a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I can monkeypatch my version to use startTagTextArea for pre and code, but I was wondering if there is a more optimal solution.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:10): a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82: Can't you escape the < to &lt; in the content of the code tag?
a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c:  not without also escaping the code tag as well
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:12): html5lib seems to do the same as what web browsers do with < inside <code>
a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: it tries to make them tags?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:14): Maybe you could use <xmp> to get <pre>-like semantics with CDATA parsing, though that'd be pretty evil :-)
a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:14): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I may as well use textarea in that case
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:14): is almost certain he's done something wrong with the uncertainties
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:15): a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82: Yes - <code>foo(<i>bar</i>)</code> is legitimate HTML and works everywhere and gives an 'i' element inside the 'code'
a75c35e47d4594898ab5dc76fcadea82 (02:16): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: right. Ok, I'll try some other ways to work around it. Thanks for the help.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:18): ¬± 0.0 I have for almost everything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): man i love it when people who right multi-page paragraphs start one of their sentences with "my point is"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): it makes my life so much easier
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:37): wishes EC2 development didn't take so long to iterate

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:38): It's like 15 minutes to start the server, then 15 minutes to persist any changes to it, plus various other bits of waiting, which is a pain when I'm trying to debug a startup script on it :-(
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: *write :P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): uh yes
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Bitching about English without even getting it right yourself‚Ä¶
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): there's an analog loop somewhere between my brain and my fingers which converts my thoughts to audio and then back again
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): it's terrible
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:43): has that too
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:43): I also have dyspraxia, so I make so many spelling mistakes I have to check what I type closely :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:44): returns to reading on uncertainties
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:49): Should I state 10.0 ¬± 0.0 or 10.0 ¬± 0.01?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:49): Neither really makes sense
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:51): The latter seems wrong because it's mixing levels of precision
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:51): What are the lower and upper bounds?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:54): The former seems wrong because it is implying it is certain, but there is an uncertainty
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:55): the last figure is always assumed to be estimated
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: 10.0 +/- 0.1 or 10.00 +/- 0.01 would seem more reasonable things to say
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Indeed
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:57): has probably gone wrong combining uncertainties
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:58): Is the uncertainty in the output of the calculation less than the uncertainty of the inputs?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:59): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: As a percentage it's double
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:08): So I have u = 85.8 ¬± 0.1
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:08): I then find f = u - u^2/100
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:08): Which makes f = 12.2 ¬± 0.0
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:09): Where is my mistake?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:12): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I think it's like err(u^2) = 2*err(u), err(u/100) = err(u)/100, err(u - v) = sqrt(err(u)^2 + err(v)^2)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:12): which comes out to 0.1 if I'm not entirely mistaken
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:12): stares
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:12): is too tired
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:12): Actually that first bit can't possible be right, can it?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:13): Oh well, whatever it is
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:13): The last step is sqrt(0.1^2 + something) so it's never going to be less than 0.1
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: The first bit is right according to the book I'm reading
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:13): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: But only if these are relative errors, I think?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: And where the hell is this v coming from?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:14): Just two terms
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:14): No relation to your u
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:14): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: This book says no such thing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:14): Ah, k
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:14): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I think it's called something with "quadrature" in the name, for calculating errors of a+b or a-b
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:14): Self-explanatory variable names, yay
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:15): but I think I'm totally failing to use relative errors when I ought to be
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:15): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: It seems fairly self-explanatory to me that v is just what comes after u :-)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:16): Let's add an error specifier to the error
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:17): http://visitmix.com/Opinions/Web-Standards-Gone-Wild

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:18): The problem with calculating error values is that it fails to account for the quite high probability that your experiment was just rubbish or that you made up all your data
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:18): So he's saying the reason we have so many buggy implementations is because the specs were too easy to implement before :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:31): If this is right, 12.4 ¬± 1.4 cm
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:31): Ow.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:32): (i.e., 12 ¬± 1 cm)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:32): That's not really 12 +/- 1
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:32): because 12.4 + 1.4 = 13.8 which is a long way from 12 + 1
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:36): Hah. It gets better.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:36): I love when positive values get errors that go into the negatives
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:39): Oh shit.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:39): Even my best results have big enough error bars to make them useless.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:40): I really can't do practical physics.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:43): had a few physics practicals in his first year, and half of them involved calculating g to increasing levels of precision
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:43): The first was something like rolling a ball down a slope, and getting something like g = 9 +/- 1
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:43): I've managed to do that as far as 9.8 ¬± 0.1
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:43): The best guy in my year got to 9.81 ¬± 0.3, IIRC
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:44): If I remember correctly, the third experiment involved some pendulum thing which was surprisingly accurate
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:44): What if you got 9.80 ¬± 0.2, would you prefer that to 9.81 ¬± 0.3?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:45): (This was doing something boring like dropping a double mask through a light-gate)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:45): I wonder how many would prefer the 9.81 one because it looks more correct :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:46): Too many :)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:48): Can we assume anything about the probability distribution within the error margins?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (03:48): I'd assume I'd done something wrong because I know that's the wrong answer
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (04:01): hit an infinite loop on gmail today
